content:
The cover of this edition of New Scientist features a striking image of the earth, with the continents and oceans depicted in crisp, clear detail. In the foreground, a large flat map of the earth is overlaid on top of the globe, highlighting the similarity between the two models. The headline of the article, "Is the Earth Flat?", is emblazoned across the top of the cover in bold, eye-catching letters.

At the bottom of the cover, a photograph of Dr. Maria Euclidios is featured, along with a brief biography highlighting her expertise in Euclidean geometry and the history of mathematical thought. The cover also includes a tagline promoting the article as a "thought-provoking exploration of a controversial idea." Overall, the cover effectively conveys the main themes and ideas of the article, and is sure to grab the attention of readers and spark their curiosity.
